title: When can you say that learning take place? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no simple answer that can adequately answer this. A beginning, however, is to say that when one has gained new knowledge or a new level of skill that was not in evidence before an event, then the event was a learning event. This idea can and should be the beginning of a ongoing discussion about learning. For example, what if that new skill or knowledge disappears after a month. Was that still learning if it was not permanent? And what constitutes as knowledge? And how does one really know that they have new knowledge—compared to what? What about quality of knowledge? What about memorization versus understanding versus application? And what about wisdom versus experience? If we reflect on our experiences, is that new knowledge?

When students are able to remember something they did not know before, or they can understand something and explain it to someone else. Or they are able to perform a task or skill without prompting. In addition, when the students can show that they have a different belief or attitude about a phenomena, or person. The only proviso to the foregoing is that you might expect higher levels exhibited as the students move up the hierarchy of learning.

Over the period of our lifetimes an enormous amount of information is processed but a limited amount of this information is stored in a neural network available for recall. It is when information can be recalled or when collective bits of information, perhaps not relevant in themselves but contributing to a solution, can be combined as relevant that we have “learned”. Our brains are the most efficient computer ever designed.

When there is understanding. When a student seems like a “pig looking at a wristwatch,” there is no understanding and certainly no learning (my sincere apologies to swine). Students must have their own “aha” moment that puts the gleam of understanding in their eyes. They must be able to ask questions that evidence they’re on the right track to understanding a concept.
The standard accepted definition of when learning occurs: When you demonstrate that you have learned. Up until then, you may be wrong.
